oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Aerial photograph of North Nashville and Jefferson Street, ca. 1968.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Aerial photograph of North Nashville in the Jefferson Street area, looking southwest, circa 1968, taken by Metro Photographer William M. King. Photograph shows a wooded residential area with several major streets running through it. Streets identified in this photo include Jefferson St., Scovel St., Heiman St., 14th Ave. North, and 18th Ave. North. Signs of construction can be seen below 18th Ave. in the upper middle of the image and at the top of the photo where land has begun to be cleared for the future route of interstate 40. Jubilee Hall on the campus of Fisk University can be seen in the upper left, with the location of Meharry Medical College marked by its smokestack behind Fisk. Lee Chapel AME church can be seen at the intersection of Scovel St. and 18th Ave. North. Forms part of the Nashville Room Historic Photographs Collection. 1 photograph : b & w ; 8 x 10 in.

This portion of Jefferson Street, close to the campuses of Fisk University and Meharry Medical College, was the center of black life and culture in Nashville at this time. The construction of the interstate destroyed significant portions of this important social and cultural hub, as well as many parts of the nearby neighborhood. The foreground of this photo is the location of a future major interchange of I-40 and I-265, which would obliterate much of this neighborhood. In 2000, Interstate 265 ceased to exist, and was redesignated as part of Interstate 65.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Lee Chapel African Methodist Episcopal Church (Nashville, Tenn.); Fisk University; Meharry Medical College
